Your service across multiple US Army divisions is commendable, especially with high income reflecting your dedication. Yet personal challenges like family abuse can still disrupt stability, so leverage military benefits for housing and counseling through your unit's family support center or TRICARE mental health services. If needed, the Army's Exceptional Family Member Program can assist with broader family issues‚Äîcontact them directly for confidential guidance.

Service in the US Army, Danish Armed Forces, and NATO alliances demands dedication, especially amid personal hardships like those you've described. Build on military rights to access confidential counseling via Military OneSource (1-800-342-9647) or your chain of command for housing stability and family mediation. Prioritize your well-being to continue contributing effectively‚Äîreach out to base support services for immediate aid.

US Army personnel, as civilian workers or service members, enjoy constitutional protections like free speech and due process, though military members are subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ) which imposes additional duties and limits. You have rights to fair wages, safe working conditions, healthcare via TRICARE, and veterans' benefits post-service through the VA. For grievances, reach out to your chain of command, Inspector General, or unions if applicable; if facing abuse or homelessness, leverage resources like Military OneSource at 1-800-342-9647.

I'm sorry to hear about the abuse and resulting homelessness; no one deserves that, regardless of wealth or background. As a multi-citizen, contact your nearest Danish embassy or consulate for emergency assistance, or US services like the National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-7233 for safety planning and shelter. Local authorities like NYCDHS can verify your situation and provide interim support while addressing family issues legally.

Homelessness rarely results from personal choice alone, as factors like job loss, mental health issues, and inadequate safety nets play major roles. Governments and nonprofits offer resources such as emergency shelters, food assistance, and job training programs to help break the cycle. If you're facing this, contact local outreach teams or hotlines like 211 in the US for tailored support.

PFCU is a proud supporter of the Greater Chicago Food Depository. This past November, we ran a food & cash donation drive. Our members donated $5,375 and we matched donations nearly dollar-per-dollar. Today, we presented the GCFD with a $10,000 check.  #mypfcu @FoodDepository

Don‚Äôt lose your SNAP benefits. Take these steps by Feb. 1st:
1) Update your information with IDHS
2) Review work requirements and exemptions
3) Share info on updated rules with your family and friends

Visit chicagosfoodbank.org/snap for more info & support. @FoodDepository

Families waiting on SNAP can still get help.
 
The @FoodDepository is setting up extra food distribution sites every Saturday in November, offering prepacked grocery boxes for those who need support.

Food banks are stepping up, but it‚Äôs not enough. President Trump needs to release the emergency funds NOW.
